texts.shortText: Sometimes cited as a synonym of Chaetomorpha linum or as C. linum f. aerea, but the two species differ considerably in both morphology and habitat, so are listed separately here.

Forms a vivid dark green mass of very long, slender, unbranched and fairly-straight filaments, each composed of a row of cylindrical cells placed end to end. The clump is attached by an enlarged basal cell about 1 mm long bearing root-like rhizoids.
Filaments about 0.2 mm wide, clump about 100 mm or more tall.

Global: Very widespread across temperate and tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
Common in highshore rockpools, often attached to rocks that are covered in a shallow layer of sand.

Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes. Also reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump.

Some sources consider the attached and unattached forms as being varieties of C. linum, but this seems extremely unlikely, as they differ greatly in both form and habitat. Thus we follow both Algaebase and the local west and south coast guides listed below, in retaining them as distinct species.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 374, as C. linum).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 98).
